caption.body: The two most spectacular forms of piña handwork include calado (pullwork) and sombrado (appliqué). Extremely fine calado entails pulling together selected fibers from the fabric to create uniform open areas in the weave; areas may then be embellished by embroidery to create a variety of geometric patterns. By the early twentieth century, calado work was limited to simple open grid patterns. The other painstaking technique, sombrado, involves a type of appliqué, in which pieces of fabric, either very fine white cotton or piña, are cut into designs; the edges are then rolled and carefully stitched onto the fabric. Rengue is a weaving technique where warp and weft threads are grouped to simulate the overall calado effect in far less time.   Design motifs on piña include leaves, vines, birds, flowers, and butterflies. There is no evidence that patterns were documented—the work was left to the imagination of the embroiderer.   See "From Pineapple to Piña: A Philippine Textile Treasure" on display, post-security, in Harvey Milk Terminal 1 and online at: https://bit.ly/PineappletoPina
caption.excerpt: The two most spectacular forms of piña handwork include calado (pullwork) and sombrado (appliqué).
